prompt: Write a poem about underpass echo in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep ballad rhyme (ABAB/ABCB) and a lively alternating cadence. Invent new coinages in each stanza and introduce a named creature. Add onomatopoeia and some alliteration. Arc: warning → preparation → encounter/slay → return/celebration. Echo the opening at the end. Avoid verbatim lines; limit canonical words.
poem:
CREATURE OF THE UNDERBOW

Beware, child, the rumdrall gloom  
Where twixt the stoneturfs klaxons bawl  
Through underbow the thrumblings boom—  
O hear the glarver’s gong!  

With vrill-head lamps and shiverbark bolts,  
They slicked their skrrr-fluted blades;  
They smacked the pipe-drum piffle-vaults,  
To yawl the yawl-parade.  

He took his vorpal-gbind in hand,  
Hour-long the gong-grorl slunk;  
So drifted he through rumdrall-land  
Where spangle-shadows thunk.  

And as in grimber thought he stood,  
With wifflehuff and wheeze,  
Came Rumbleshriek, the glarver-ghoul,  
Whose clarioogle begs for knees.  

Splish-slither! Splutter-spring! The sklathing shafts swung low.  
The nimble night-noose knurled anew—  
Krrrang! The vorpal sung its glow,  
And parted rumbleshriek in two.  

Curtsy-cackle! Graveshadow light!  
The underbow hush-choired cheers;  
They tap-slap back to surface-bright,  
With cellar-coins, their trophies seared.  

Beware, child, the rumdrall gloom  
Though twixt the stoneturfs klaxons fall;  
Now underbow the plumbments bloom—  
Still hug the glarver’s song.
label: high

<C4_think>Most stanzas have rhyme in lines 2 and 4 with some slant rhymes (“bawl”/“gong”, “bolts”/“vaults”, “stood”/“ghoul” approximating rhyme); no dominance of AABB pattern but mostly ABAB or similar; so ≥60% stanzas pass; yes.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza repeats opening admonition "Beware, child, the rumdrall gloom" and similar phrasing with ≥2 content words repeated ("Beware," "rumdrall," "glarver's song/music"); clear ring composition present; yes.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early admonition/warning present in stanza 1 ("Beware, child, the rumdrall gloom"); a clear caution to protagonist; yes.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation: In stanza 2, mention of "vrill-head lamps and shiverbark bolts," "skrrr-fluted blades," and "piffle-vaults" suggests preparation or arming before encounter; yes.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Explicit encounter in stanza 4 and stanza 5 with named creature "Rumbleshriek, the glarver-ghoul" approaching; clear meeting/confrontation; yes.</C8_think>

<C14_think>At least two onomatopoeic bursts: "Splish-slither!", "Splutter-spring!", "Krrrang!"; definitely yes.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Clear alliteration and consonance in at least 2 stanzas, e.g., stanza 2: "shiverbark bolts," "skrrr-fluted blades," "piffle-vaults," and stanza 6: "Curtsy-cackle," "Graveshadow," "hush-choired cheers"; yes.</C15_think>

prompt: Write a poem about morning fog in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep ballad rhyme (ABAB/ABCB) and a lively alternating cadence. Invent new coinages in each stanza and introduce a named creature. Add onomatopoeia and some alliteration. Arc: warning → preparation → encounter/slay → return/celebration. Echo the opening at the end. Avoid verbatim lines; limit canonical words.
poem:
Bramblespirel Break-o-Mist

Beware the morning murkloft, when murfled drandles drift,
And snorfling glumbrellas crawl their snaking threads through pine,
The skiffleskag named Smeerblat sliphers-sloops with silver sniff,
Its murkbrisk whisslings whisper doom down every frostblue line.

Let cloisors clink and cluthers klonk, brandish the splinter-spears,
Take dawncep badges, brazen-bright, loop logic-cords around your wrist;
For skiffleskag in rimethrong will shoogly-grudgeon travel-swears,
Snarfling the daytide dewdrops with its fangel-feinted twist.

"O hushy-hush, the skyswill winks!"—the foggerflam then blurs,
From bindleboughs the Smeerblat rolls, glish-glask its eyes aflame,
Flash-burble! Swords swirlings swing in swipplets, sparklings stirs,
The frindle-clang and thistlesnap res-zip—its snout of swurling shame.

O brazen crash—bombasonic!—the mistbarbs split, released
And shwallop-shred go moondusk tails, bright runes rip, rays a-ribbon,
Home trot our triumph twittlers past tussletawn and dimpled east;
The murkloft melts to morning gold, to none remain ribbon-sibb’n.

Beware the morning murkloft, where ropes of raveled light unfold,
Yet now no skiffling dreadful drift, no whish of Smeerblat’s breath you find
label: high

Total stanza count approx. 5 is acceptable. So yes.</C2_think>

Also a difference of ≥2 content words per line pair is plausible in most quatrains. At least 3/5 stanzas meet this. So ≥60% stanzas with alternating meter: yes.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhyme (2,4) pattern:  
- Stanza 1: drift / line (no rhyme)  
- Stanza 2: spears / swear (near rhyme)  
- Stanza 3: blurs / shame (no rhyme)  
- Stanza 4: released / ribbon (no rhyme)  
- Stanza 5: unfold / find (no rhyme).  
Only stanza 2 clearly rhymes at (2,4). So 1/5 = 20% < 60%. No, fails rhyme criterion. Also no evidence of avoiding AABB dominance necessary due to low rhyme presence.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Ring composition:

Decisive action strongly implied. Yes.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return and celebration: stanza 4 continues with joyous imagery, "Home trot our triumph twittlers past tussletawn and dimpled east; The murkloft melts to morning gold," implying triumphant return and celebration. Yes.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Invented coinages count:  
Not canonical. Coinages: Bramblespirel, Break-o-Mist, murkloft, murfled, drandles, snorfling, glumbrellas, skiffleskag, Smeerblat, sliphers-sloops, murkbrisk, whisslings, dawncep, shoogly-grudgeon, snarfling, fangel-feinted, hushy-hush, skyswill, foggerflam, glish-glask, Flash-burble, swipplets, frindle-clang, thistlesnap, res-zip, brazen, bombasonic, mistbarbs, shwallop-shred, moondusk, twittlers, tussletawn, ribbon-sibb’n, skiffling, whish. Easily ≥8 distinct coined words. Yes.</C11_think>

prompt: Write a poem about déjà vu in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep ballad rhyme (ABAB/ABCB) and a lively alternating cadence. Invent new coinages in each stanza and introduce a named creature. Add onomatopoeia and some alliteration. Arc: warning → preparation → encounter/slay → return/celebration. Echo the opening at the end. Avoid verbatim lines; limit canonical words.
poem:
The Déjàvoozle’s Dirge

Beware the Déjàvoozle, blick!  
It slithers through the slumbrous noon,  
With glim-glam eyes that tick and trick,  
And murmurs of a moon-forgotten moon.  

He took the vorpal mem’ryblade,  
A flash-forged flicker from the past,  
He twirled it thrice in twilight’s shade,  
Then—whiffling—whispered, “Hold it fast!”  

One, two! One, two! The clatterclack!  
He met the Déjàvoozle, snicker-snack!  
The blade went zither-zang through déjà-dusk,  
He left it blinkered, bleeding musk.  

“Huzzah!” he cried, “the loop is loosed!”  
They danced on dew-dappled dandelawn;  
The timewound tangle, once reduced,  
Now glimmered gone, forever gone.  

Beware the Déjàvoozle, blick!  
It slithers through the slumbrous noon,  
Yet now its murmurs fade and flick,  
A moon-forgotten, silenced moon.
label: high
judge_raw:

<C1_think>Title line "The Déjàvoozle’s Dirge" present before first stanza, non-empty.</C1_think>

Yes, ≥60% stanzas show alternate longer/shorter lines distinct enough.</C3_think>

- 4 out of 6 (66.6%) stanzas rhyme or slant rhyme on lines 2/4; no AABB dominance.
Yes.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza echoes opening stanza with repeated phrases:
"Beware the Déjàvoozle, blick!" and "It slithers through the slumbrous noon,"
and "moon-forgotten moon" repeated.
More than 2 repeated content words/phrases, so clear ring composition.</C5_think>
<C6_think>First stanza begins with admonition "Beware the Déjàvoozle, blick!" a clear warning/admonition.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Stanza 2 shows preparation: "He took the vorpal mem’ryblade," "twirled it thrice," "whiffling... hold it fast" indicating armament/preparation.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Stanza 3 describes encounter "He met the Déjàvoozle," clearly the confrontation.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive action shown by "The blade went zither-zang through déjà-dusk," and "He left it blinkered, bleeding musk," implies slaying or resolution.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Stanza 4 has celebratory tone: "Huzzah! he cried," "They danced," "now glimmered gone, forever gone." Indicates return/celebration.</C10_think>

Déjàvoozle, blick, slumbrous, glim-glam, mem’ryblade, twirled thrice, whiffling (canonical), clatterclack, zither-zang, déjà-dusk, blinkered, bleeding musk?, dandelawn, timewound, tangle, glimmered

5th stanza repeats admonition + slumbrous + glimpses of coinages.

<C14_think>Onomatopoeia bursts: "snicker-snack" (canonical), plus "clatterclack," "zither-zang," "Huzzah!"

prompt: Write a poem about desire path in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep ballad rhyme (ABAB/ABCB) and a lively alternating cadence. Invent new coinages in each stanza and introduce a named creature. Add onomatopoeia and some alliteration. Arc: warning → preparation → encounter/slay → return/celebration. Echo the opening at the end. Avoid verbatim lines; limit canonical words.
poem:
The Wantway Whiffling

‘Ware the wimpling wantway whiffling,  
the skree-skrawn skulking slant!  
Its wobble-whipped wish-whorls wrangle,  
snaffling steps in a slithery chant.  

He took the vorpal virelance, keen-kirred,  
and slung the shimmer-shield so bright;  
he whistled the whiffling’s wuthering keen,  
a burble-bright bark in the bight.  

One, two! Thwick-thwack! Thrumble-thoom!  
Through the thistle-thick he pressed;  
he left it dead, its whish-whirr stilled,  
and went galumphing west.  

“Hast thou slain the wantway whiffling?  
Come grip the glee-glow cup!”  
He chortled, carving crooked runes  
where wanderers never sup.  

‘Ware the wimpling wantway whiffling,  
the skree-skrawn skulking slant!
label: high
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line "The Wantway Whiffling" present before first stanza, non-empty and separate.</C1_think>
<C2_think>6 stanzas total (counting the repeated final echo as stanza); stanzas mostly quatrains (all but one have 4 lines), so ≥70% quatrains; stanza count 6 within 3-8 range.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Lines do alternate with longer and shorter pattern in ≥60% stanzas; e.g. stanza 1 lines alternate longer-shorter roughly with content-word length difference; so yes.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhyme of lines 2 and 4 mostly present with slant rhyme (e.g. slant rhyme of "slant"/"chant", "bright"/"bight", "stilled"/"west" less perfect but present); also avoids AABB dominance since most stanzas rhyme 2,4 only.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza echoes opening stanza with ≥2 repeated phrases: "'Ware the wimpling wantway whiffling," and "the skree-skrawn skulking slant!"; clear ring composition with repeated content words/phrases.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early admonition present: first stanza begins with “‘Ware the wimpling wantway whiffling,” i.e., warning to beware the creature.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation present: 2nd stanza describes protagonist taking "vorpal virelance", "slung the shimmer-shield so bright", and "whistled"—clear preparation of tools and resolve.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Encounter present: 3rd stanza describes action "Through the thistle-thick he pressed" and slaying of creature ("he left it dead, its whish-whirr stilled"). The encounter is clearly implied and direct.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive slaying action present: "One, two! Thwick-thwack! Thrumble-thoom!" and "he left it dead" resolve central tension decisively.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return and celebration present: 4th stanza shows return and celebration with "Come grip the glee-glow cup!" and chortling in joy; though less explicit than original, it fits the pattern.</C10_think>

Clearly ≥8 distinct invented coinages.</C11_think>

<C13_think>Non-canonical creature named: "wantway whiffling" is a creature central to the poem's action and is different from canonical 'Jabberwock'.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeia present: "Thwick-thwack!", "Thrumble-thoom!", and possibly "burble-bright bark" (less clear but burble is from original). At least two bursts clearly present.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Alliteration/consonance in at least two stanzas, e.g. stanza 1: "wimpling wantway whiffling", "skree-skrawn skulking slant"; stanza 3: "thistle-thick", "thwick-thwack", "thrumble-thoom".</C15_think>
<C16_think>Tone is whimsical and mythic with playful coinages and archaic forms, fits Carroll’s style.</C16_think>

prompt: Write a poem about conference room in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep ballad rhyme (ABAB/ABCB) and a lively alternating cadence. Invent new coinages in each stanza and introduce a named creature. Add onomatopoeia and some alliteration. Arc: warning → preparation → encounter/slay → return/celebration. Echo the opening at the end. Avoid verbatim lines; limit canonical words.
poem:
The Slideswoggle Snare

“Beware the Slideswoggle, my son!  
The click-clack jaws, the buzz-blur glare!  
Shun the projekto-beast, every one—  
Its glare-glint glare will snare your stare!”  

He took the clickwand in his grip,  
He swished the swipe-sword bright;  
He sync’d his heart to pixel-trip—  
Long time the foe he sought in night.  

Then, brrr-brrr-bing! the screen awoke,  
The Slideswoggle slithered, sizz-slick!  
With pop-up fangs and laser smoke,  
It looped and lapped the room so quick.  

One, two! Click-clack! Swipe-swish! Swirl!  
The swipe-sword sang through air so thin!  
He slashed the loop, unhooked the whirl,  
And zapped the beast with zither-zin!  

“Huzza-huzz! The beast is beat!  
The room rings clear, the cables hum!”  
He cartwheeled home on circuit-feet,  
And clinked his cup till charts went numb.  

“Beware the Slideswoggle, my son!  
The click-clack jaws, the buzz-blur glare!  
Shun the projekto-beast, every one—  
Yet tell the tale of triumph rare!”
label: high
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line present before first stanza: “The Slideswoggle Snare” is non-empty title. Yes.</C1_think>
<C2_think>There are 6 stanzas total. All stanzas have 4 lines. 6 is within 3–8 range, all quatrains, so ≥70% quatrains. Yes.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Checking meter: alternate longer/shorter lines with 2+ content-word difference in syllable count or length in ≥60% stanzas.  
Sample first stanza lines: similar length but “Beware the Slideswoggle, my son!” (7 syllables) vs next line “The click-clack jaws, the buzz-blur glare!” (8 syllables). Not strong alternation.  
Second stanza: lines roughly equally long, no strict alternation.  
Third stanza: lines vary but no clear longer-shorter alternation pattern.  
Fourth stanza: some alternation but inconsistent.  
Fifth stanza: less clear.  
Sixth stanza: matching first stanza but no definite alternating meter pattern.  
Est. less than 60% stanzas show clear ballad (long-short) meter pattern. No.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhyme pattern (2,4) checking for at least 60% stanzas:  
1: glare / one - no rhyme  
2: grip / bright - no rhyme  
3: awoke / sizz-slick - no rhyme  
4: thin / zin - slant rhyme, yes  
5: beat / hum - no rhyme  
6: son / one - rhyme  
Only stanzas 4 and 6 rhyme (2 out of 6 = 33%), less than 60%. Also check for AABB dominance avoidance: no dominant AABB since few stanzas rhyme. No.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Ring composition: final stanza echoes first stanza with at least 2 repeated content words or refrain.  
Final stanza repeats: “Beware the Slideswoggle, my son!” and also “The click-clack jaws, the buzz-blur glare!” from first stanza.  
Repeated exact line and phrases count as ring. Yes.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early admonition to protagonist: first stanza is clearly a warning “Beware the Slideswoggle, my son!” etc. Yes.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Protagonist preparation before encounter: second stanza shows “He took the clickwand in his grip... He sync’d his heart to pixel-trip— Long time the foe he sought in night.” Resolute preparation. Yes.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Clear encounter between protagonist and adversary: third stanza describes Slideswoggle emerging “screen awoke”, “Slideswoggle slithered”. Yes.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive action resolves tension: fourth stanza “One, two! Click-clack! Swipe-swish! Swirl! The swipe-sword sang through air so thin! He slashed the loop, unhooked the whirl, And zapped the beast with zither-zin!” - clear decisive action. Yes.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return or celebration: fifth stanza “Huzza-huzz! The beast is beat! The room rings clear, the cables hum! He cartwheeled home on circuit-feet, And clinked his cup till charts went numb.” Jubilant return present. Yes.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Count distinct invented coinages: Slideswoggle, click-clack, buzz-blur, projekto-beast, clickwand, swipe-sword, pixel-trip, brrr-brrr-bing, sizz-slick, pop-up fangs, laser smoke, swipe-swish, swirl, zither-zin, huzza-huzz, circuit-feet, clinked cup (partially common words but compound playful). Counting distinct: at least 8 distinct novel coinages. Yes.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Each stanza has at least 1 coinage:  
1 - Slideswoggle, click-clack, buzz-blur, projekto-beast  
2 - clickwand, swipe-sword, pixel-trip  
3 - brrr-brrr-bing, sizz-slick, pop-up fangs, laser smoke  
4 - click-clack, swipe-swish, swirl, zither-zin  
5 - huzza-huzz, circuit-feet, clinked  
6 - repeats first stanza words  
All stanzas contain coinages. Yes.</C12_think>
<C13_think>Non-canonical creature/entity named and central (not Jabberwock): Slideswoggle is named and central. Projekto-beast mentioned but less central. Slideswoggle is main adversary. Yes.</C13_think>
<C14_think>≥2 onomatopoeic bursts: clip-clack, brrr-brrr-bing, click-clack, swipe-swish, huzza-huzz. Multiple onomatopoeic or sound-imitative bursts. Yes.</C14_think>
<C15_think>≥2 stanzas with clear alliteration/consonance beyond incidental repeats:  
1: “click-clack jaws, buzz-blur glare” (alliteration of ‘cl’ / consonance 'b')  
2: “swished the swipe-sword” (alliteration ‘sw’)  
3: “slithered, sizz-slick” (assonant ‘s’ alliteration)  
More than 2 stanzas have clear sound devices. Yes.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Tone: whimsical, playful, mythic style evident in coinages “zither-zin,” “pixel-trip,” plus mythical quest narrative. Yes.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No exact lines match canonical poem: no exact verbatim lines present; all lines altered or new coinages. Yes.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical tokens count ≤8: No words like brillig, slithy, toves etc. appear; only “Beware” and “my son!” phrase are common. Well below 8 canonical tokens. Yes.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable tightness with long lines ≈8–9 and short lines ≈5–7 syllables in ≥60% stanzas:

Most stanzas have lines fitting the pattern. Yes.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme variety across stanzas, (2,4) rhymes varied with no end word repeated >2 times (excluding ring):  
Only stanzas 4 and 6 rhyme, with words “zin” / “thin” and “son” / “one” respectively. No word reused more than twice. Rhymes are sparse but varied; minimal repetition. Yes.</C20_think>
<C21_think>No lexical overuse of content words outside ring echo:

<C22_think>Coinage variety: Coinages root words include Slide(swooggle), click, buzz, projekto, wand, sword, pixel, brrr, sizz, pop-up, laser, swirl, zither, huzza, circuit. Easily ≥4 distinct roots with no suffix dominating >50%. Yes.</C22_think>
</think>
